addIdeas.title: AI-Resilient Assignment Redesign + Rubric Language
addIdeas.deliverable: Assignment sheet + rubric + AI disclosure language
steps: State the learning outcomes and the non-negotiable evidence students must show (process, citations, reflection).
Add checkpoints: proposal → annotated sources → draft → reflection (and require process evidence at each step).
Generate a rubric draft that rewards transparent process and penalizes unsupported claims.
Draft a short, neutral AI use/disclosure statement aligned to your policy stance.
notes: Include a verification step: spot-check claims and citations against primary sources.
Ensure the activity works with and without AI (no requirement to use AI tools).

addReflection: If students use AI, what evidence of learning will you require that cannot be substituted by a tool output?
How will you communicate acceptable vs unacceptable AI use (examples help)?

addIdeas.title: Literature Landscape Scan + Citation Chaining Workflow
addIdeas.deliverable: Search log + reading set + citation map + initial theme clusters
steps: Start with 2–3 seed papers in Semantic Scholar; follow references and 'cited by' to expand.
Use ResearchRabbit to map related clusters and identify influential nodes/authors.
Use Perplexity to generate keyword expansions and contested terms (verify using scholarly sources).
Create a reading list with inclusion/exclusion notes and a simple decision trail.
notes: Document your search strategy for reproducibility (dates, queries, databases, filters).
Treat any summaries as hypotheses; validate in full text.

addReflection: What is your reproducibility plan (search log, prompts/queries, versioning, decision trail)?

addIdeas.title: Evidence Table + Synthesis Pipeline (with Verification)
addIdeas.deliverable: Evidence table (methods/sample/findings/limits) + theme synthesis outline
steps: Extract structured fields into an evidence table (method, sample, intervention, outcomes, limitations).
Cluster studies into 3–6 themes; write a synthesis outline with claims supported by citations.
Use Scite (if selected) to check citation contexts (supporting vs contrasting), then verify in the paper.
Draft your 'limitations and uncertainty' section early to avoid overclaiming.
notes: Always verify quotes/claims/citations against the original PDF.
Maintain transparency: note which parts were tool-assisted and which were human-authored.

addIdeas.title: Data-to-Story: Visualization + Narrative Alignment
addIdeas.deliverable: Clean chart(s) + narrative paragraph + limitations note
steps: Define what decision the figure supports (what should a reader conclude?).
Generate 2–3 candidate visualizations; choose the clearest (avoid misleading axes/encodings).
Write a 150–250 word interpretive caption: what the chart shows, what it does NOT show, and caveats.
Add a short 'data provenance' line (source, timeframe, transformations).
notes: Check for accessibility: alt text or a textual description of key trends.
Confirm statistical claims with manual reasoning and/or a second method.

addIdeas.title: Optional Media Asset Pack for Teaching (Non-Instructional)
addIdeas.deliverable: 3–5 non-instructional assets (intro/outro, course announcement visual, accessibility-friendly captions)
steps: Decide the purpose: outreach, announcements, or transitions (avoid generating instructional content if policy requires).
Create a style guide: tone, colors, typography, and any institutional constraints.
Generate assets, then do a human QA pass (accuracy, appropriateness, IP, accessibility).
Add alt text/captions and store source prompts for transparency.
notes: Avoid using student-identifiable information or real people without consent.
Confirm platform terms and institutional guidance.

addIdeas.title: Research Communication: Animated Abstract (Optional)
addIdeas.deliverable: 60–120 sec animated abstract storyboard + script + clip list
steps: Write a plain-language abstract (150–200 words) and identify 3 key claims to visualize.
Storyboard 6–10 scenes; choose non-realistic visuals to avoid uncanny-valley risks.
Generate short clips; edit and caption in a standard editor; keep a source log of prompts and assets.
Add a disclosure slide describing tool-assisted steps and human verification.
notes: Avoid making factual claims visually unless you can cite/verify the underlying data.
Ensure accessibility: captions, clear pacing, and readable text.

addIdeas.title: Annotated Evidence Portfolio Assignment
addIdeas.deliverable: Annotated evidence portfolio + reflective synthesis
steps: Students identify 6–10 peer-reviewed sources using discovery + lit review tools.
Students extract structured evidence (methods, sample, findings, limits).
Students cluster sources into thematic groups and justify grouping logic.
Students write a reflective synthesis explaining knowledge gaps and disagreements.
notes: Require citation verification against full text.
Include reflection on tool reliability.

addIdeas.title: AI Output Critique Workshop
addIdeas.deliverable: Comparative critique of AI-generated vs human-authored responses
steps: Provide students with AI-generated answers and human-written answers.
Students identify factual accuracy, bias, and rhetorical effectiveness.
Students revise AI outputs using scholarly evidence.
Students submit reflection on limitations of AI assistance.

addIdeas.title: Research Gap Identification Workflow
addIdeas.deliverable: Gap analysis memo + preliminary research question refinement
steps: Generate topic landscape using discovery tools.
Map dominant themes and underexplored subtopics.
Evaluate methodological patterns across literature.
Draft research questions aligned to identified gaps.

addIdeas.title: Exploratory Data Interpretation Notebook
addIdeas.deliverable: Data notebook combining visualization, narrative interpretation, and methodological notes
steps: Import dataset and generate initial exploratory visualizations.
Annotate charts with narrative interpretations and statistical caveats.
Identify potential confounding variables.
Produce reproducibility documentation.

addIdeas.title: Reading-to-Teaching Translation Project
addIdeas.deliverable: Instructional module derived from research literature
steps: Upload research articles into NotebookLM.
Generate structured summaries and thematic connections.
Translate findings into lesson modules or case studies.
Create discussion prompts grounded in research evidence.

addIdeas.title: Student Media Literacy Analysis
addIdeas.deliverable: Comparative analysis of AI-generated vs authentic media artifacts
steps: Generate sample AI media artifacts.
Compare with authentic scholarly or journalistic artifacts.
Analyze credibility indicators and misinformation risks.
Write critical evaluation report.

addIdeas.title: Program-Level AI Impact Audit
addIdeas.deliverable: Program AI readiness and risk evaluation report
steps: Map curricular areas where AI is currently used or emerging.
Identify potential academic integrity and equity risks.
Develop program-level disclosure or usage guidelines.
Propose faculty development initiatives.

addIdeas.title: AI Micro-Activity Discussion Starter
addIdeas.deliverable: 15-minute class discussion exercise
steps: Generate a controversial or ambiguous claim related to course content.
Have students fact-check using scholarly databases.
Facilitate group comparison of verification strategies.
Conclude with a reflection on source evaluation.

addIdeas.title: Capstone Research Design Scaffold
addIdeas.deliverable: Full research design proposal outline
steps: Generate background literature summary.
Develop theoretical framework and research questions.
Draft methodology with justification.
Include data management and ethics planning section.

addIdeas.title: Active-Learning Redesign (Topic-Aware)
addIdeas.deliverable: 1 class session plan + materials + participation rubric
steps: Identify the hardest concept in your topic and write 3 common misconceptions.
Design a 10–15 minute activity (think–pair–share, jigsaw, case analysis) that surfaces misconceptions.
Create a quick formative check (1–3 questions) and a 2–3 line feedback script.
Add an optional extension task for advanced students and an accessibility-friendly alternative.
notes: Ensure the activity is AI-optional: learning evidence is observable without tool use.

addReflection: What observable evidence will tell you students understood the concept (beyond producing a polished answer)?

addIdeas.title: Clinical Case Synthesis + Verification Protocol
addIdeas.deliverable: Case brief + evidence table + verification checklist
steps: Draft a de-identified case prompt (no patient identifiers) and define learning objectives.
Build an evidence table: guideline/source, recommendation, strength of evidence, caveats.
Create a verification checklist: cross-check claims against 2+ clinical sources (guidelines/textbook).
Add a reflection: uncertainty, contraindications, and scope limits.
notes: Avoid any real patient data; keep all scenarios fictional or fully de-identified.
Require citations from authoritative clinical sources.

addReflection: How will you prevent overconfidence (hallucinations) from becoming clinical-sounding misinformation?

addIdeas.title: Stakeholder + Market Analysis Brief
addIdeas.deliverable: 1–2 page brief + competitor table + assumptions log
steps: Define the entity/problem and list stakeholders with incentives and constraints.
Build a competitor/alternative table (at least 6 entries) with evidence for each claim.
Separate assumptions vs verified facts; label confidence levels.
Write a recommendation section with risks and metrics for success.
notes: Require citations for market claims; avoid unverifiable numbers without sources.

addReflection: Which claims require primary or authoritative data (e.g., filings, industry reports) rather than summaries?

addIdeas.title: Close-Reading + Argument Map (Humanities)
addIdeas.deliverable: Argument map + annotated passage set + thesis revisions
steps: Select 2–4 key passages and annotate claims, warrants, and rhetorical moves.
Build an argument map: thesis → reasons → evidence → counterarguments.
Write 2 competing theses; defend each with different interpretive frames.
Add a methods note: what counts as evidence in this discipline for this task.
notes: If using any tool to draft language, require a process reflection grounded in the text.

addReflection: How will you assess interpretive responsibility (fidelity to text/context) rather than surface fluency?

addIdeas.title: Reproducible Mini-Study + Error Analysis (STEM)
addIdeas.deliverable: Methods note + results figure + error/assumption analysis
steps: Define a narrow question and a minimal dataset or simulation approach.
Create a reproducible workflow log (inputs, parameters, versions).
Generate a figure + short results paragraph with uncertainty/limitations.
Write an error analysis: what could invalidate the result and how you tested robustness.
notes: Emphasize transparency: versioning, parameter choices, and reproducibility.

addReflection: What is your plan to detect and correct silent errors (unit mistakes, parameter drift, misleading plots)?

addIdeas.title: Mixed-Methods Study Blueprint + Ethics Checklist
addIdeas.deliverable: Study blueprint + instrument draft + ethics/IRB readiness notes
steps: Draft 2–3 research questions and align each to a method (survey, interview, archival, experiment).
Design a minimal instrument (10–12 survey items OR 6–8 interview prompts).
Create a coding plan (themes, codebook starter) or analysis plan (models/tests).
Write an ethics checklist: consent, confidentiality, data retention, disclosure.
notes: Ensure tools are not used to process identifiable participant data unless approved.

addReflection: What data elements are sensitive, and what is your approved plan for storage, access, and retention?

addIdeas.title: Intro Course: Source-Evaluation Lab
addIdeas.deliverable: Source-evaluation worksheet + grading key
steps: Provide 6 sources of varying quality on the topic (2 scholarly, 2 popular, 2 questionable).
Students rate each using criteria: authority, evidence, methods, currency, bias.
Students rewrite one claim into an evidence-supported paragraph with citations.
Close with a short reflection on how tool outputs can mislead without verification.

addIdeas.title: Grad-Level Review Protocol Starter
addIdeas.deliverable: Protocol outline + inclusion/exclusion + PRISMA-ready tracking sheet
steps: Define the review type (systematic/scoping) and the research question.
Write inclusion/exclusion criteria and databases to search.
Draft screening workflow (title/abstract → full text) and disagreement resolution method.
Create a PRISMA-ready tracking log and data extraction fields.
notes: Tool outputs may assist with organization, but final screening decisions require human review.

addIdeas.title: Seed-to-Table Pipeline (Semantic Scholar → Elicit)
addIdeas.deliverable: Reading set + extraction table + theme map
steps: Use Semantic Scholar to build a seed set (10–20) via citation chaining.
Import the final set into Elicit for structured extraction.
Cluster studies into themes and write a synthesis outline with citations.
Add verification: spot-check 5 extracted items against PDFs.

addIdeas.title: Evidence-to-Visualization Synthesis (Lit Review → Data/Viz)
addIdeas.deliverable: Figure + narrative synthesis paragraph + limitations
steps: Extract key variables/findings into a table.
Create one comparative visualization (by method, year, population, outcome).
Write a narrative connecting the figure to 2–3 claims with citations.
Add limitations and uncertainty statements explicitly.

addIdeas.title: AI Policy Position Memo + Evidence Trail
addIdeas.deliverable: Position memo + sources + implementation checklist
steps: Define the scope: classroom policy, research policy, or program policy.
Summarize 3 stakeholder perspectives and their concerns.
Support claims with citations; separate evidence from opinion.
Draft an implementation checklist (communication, training, enforcement, review cycle).

addReflection: What is the minimum transparency standard you will require (disclosure, citation, verification) and why?

addIdeas.title: Accessible Course Communications Pack (Optional GenAI)
addIdeas.deliverable: Announcement visuals + alt text + captioned micro-video script
steps: Define the communication goal (reminder, schedule change, office hours, resource highlight).
Generate 2–3 variants; select one based on clarity and accessibility.
Write alt text and a plain-language caption.
Do a final QA pass for institutional tone and IP/copyright constraints.
notes: Do not include student-specific information in generated assets.

addIdeas.title: Research Poster / Slide Narrative Assets (Optional GenAI)
addIdeas.deliverable: Figure style guide + icons/visuals + disclosure slide
steps: Define 3 key claims and identify what needs a visual (diagram, pipeline, conceptual map).
Generate non-photoreal visuals and standardize style (colors/fonts).
Add a disclosure slide explaining tool-assisted steps and human verification.
Archive prompts/assets for documentation.

addIdeas.title: Tool-Assisted vs Tool-Free Search Strategy Comparison
addIdeas.deliverable: Comparison worksheet + reflective write-up
steps: Students perform a traditional database search and document query evolution.
Students perform a tool-assisted search (if permitted) and document outputs.
Students compare results: relevance, bias, missing voices, and citation quality.
Students write a short reflection: where tools helped vs harmed, and how to verify.

addIdeas.title: Revision Studio: Claims, Evidence, and Counterarguments
addIdeas.deliverable: Revised draft + revision memo
steps: Identify 3 central claims; label each as descriptive/causal/normative.
For each claim, require at least one high-quality source and a counterargument.
Revise for clarity and structure; add signposting and transitions.
Write a revision memo describing what changed and why (process evidence).

addIdeas.title: Grant Narrative Scaffold + Compliance Checklist
addIdeas.deliverable: Narrative outline + broader impacts/significance + compliance checklist
steps: Draft significance/need statement with citations.
Write aims/objectives and an evaluation plan (metrics, timeline).
Create a data management plan and dissemination plan.
Add compliance checks: human subjects, IP, accessibility, and disclosure norms.
